Introduction

Respiratory neurobiology involves the structures and feedback mechanisms that determine breathing patterns and minute ventilation.  Respiratory control can be thought of as a central pattern generator (CPG) (brainstem) with both voluntary inputs (eg, cortical override) and involuntary inputs (eg, chemoreceptors).

Central pattern generator



The respiratory CPG is a group of brainstem structures that work together to create a normal, unconscious (automatic) tidal breathing pattern.  The CPG consists of the medullary and pontine respiratory centers (

figure 1
).

Medullary respiratory center



The medullary respiratory center sets the tidal respiratory rate.  It contains:



  • A pacemaker nucleus (the pre-BÃ¶tzinger complex):  This structure consists of thousands of neurons that spontaneously depolarize (eg, If sodium leak channel), establishing automaticity.
  • A motor nucleus (the ventral respiratory group [VRG]):  It receives rhythm input from the pacemaker and sends output to the phrenic motor nucleus (C3-5) to initiate diaphragm contraction and inspiratory effort; it also projects motor neurons to the accessory muscles of breathing.
  • A sensory nucleus (the dorsal respiratory group [DRG]):  It receives afferent signals from chemoreceptors (eg, pH, CO2, O2) and mechanoreceptors (eg, pulmonary stretch).  The DRG integrates these signals and accelerates or decelerates the pacemaker nucleus, subsequently quickening or slowing the respiratory rate.

Pontine respiratory center



The pontine respiratory center sets the inspiratory time.  It consists of the pneumotaxic and apneustic centers.  They have opposing effects on the VRG, which activates the diaphragm.



  • The pneumotaxic center shortens inspiration (tonic effect).
  • The apneustic center prolongs inspiration.


The balance between them determines the transition between inspiration and expiration.  Under normal conditions, inspiration (I) lasts half as long as expiration (E) does (ie, I:E = 1:2) because the pneumotaxic center dominates.  Obstructive conditions are associated with longer expiration (eg, I:E = 1:3), whereas restrictive conditions are associated with longer inspiration (eg, I:E = 1:1).

Modulators of the central pattern generator



The unconscious CPG can be modulated by voluntary control (eg, cortex), emotional responses (eg, limbic system), and feedback from chemoreceptors (pH, CO2, O2) and mechanoreceptors.

Cortical and limbic input



  • Cortical input (voluntary):  Respiratory patterns can be controlled by the premotor and motor cortices (eg, speech, singing).  However, if pH drops or CO2 levels rise excessively (eg, prolonged breath holding), the medullary respiratory center overrides the cortex, triggering an involuntary breath.
  • Limbic input (involuntary):  Strong emotions (eg, fear, excitement) can cause involuntary changes in respiration via the amygdala and other limbic structures (cingulate cortex, hypothalamus) that project to the respiratory centers.

Chemoreceptor input



Chemoreceptors regulate respiration by detecting changes in pH, CO2, and O2 and adjusting breathing patterns accordingly (

).  In order of importance:



  • Arterial pH (H+) and CO2:  These are sensed by peripheral chemoreceptors (aortic arch, carotid bodies), which send afferents to the DRG via the vagus nerve (CN X) (aortic arch) and the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) (carotid body) (
    figure 2
    ).  Low pH (acidosis) or high CO2 (hypercapnia) stimulates respiratory rate and depth.

    • Low arterial pH is a more powerful stimulus than CO2 and usually causes marked dyspnea.  For example, during diabetic ketoacidosis (eg, pH 7.28), patients continue to hyperventilate (eg, Kussmaul breathing) despite low PaCO2 (eg, 17 mm Hg).  In addition, unlike pH receptors, CO2 chemoreceptors become desensitized with chronic hypercapnia and renal compensation (eg, obesity hypoventilation syndrome).
    • Central chemoreceptors in the medulla sense CO2 indirectly by detecting changes in H+ concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).  When CO2 diffuses into the CSF, it creates H+ (ie, CO2 + H2O â‡Œ H2CO3 â‡Œ H+ + HCO3) with the help of carbonic anhydrase.
  • Arterial O2:  This is also sensed by peripheral chemoreceptors in the aortic arch and carotid bodies.  Low O2 (hypoxemia) stimulates respiratory rate and depth.  Compared to pH and CO2, hypoxemia is a weaker stimulus and generally does not cause significant dyspnea.

Mechanoreceptor input



Breathing patterns can be modulated by afferents from mechanoreceptors in the lungs.



  • Pulmonary stretch receptors are mechanosensitive ion channels located primarily in the airway wall, blood vessels, and pleural surfaces.  The key receptors, Piezo1 and Piezo2, convert mechanical deformation into electrical signals (ie, piezoelectric effect).  When the lungs expand, these receptors send inhibitory signals to the medullary respiratory center, terminating inspiration to prevent lung overinflation (Hering-Breuer reflex).
  • Alveolar juxtacapillary receptors (C fibers) are chemosensitive and mechanosensitive sensory nerves located in the alveolar septa near pulmonary capillaries.  They respond to pulmonary congestion (eg, edema), inflammation, and noxious stimuli.  Activation triggers afferent signals via the vagus nerve to the medullary respiratory center, producing a sensation of dyspnea and reflex tachypnea.

Abnormal respiratory patterns

"-pneas"



Abnormal breath types are formally referred to by the suffix "-pnea":



  • Tachypnea refers to an abnormally rapid respiratory rate (eg, >20/min at rest).
  • Hyperpnea refers to an abnormally deep inspiratory volume.
  • Bradypnea refers to an abnormally slow respiratory rate (eg, <12/min at rest).
  • Hypopnea refers to an abnormally shallow inspiratory volume.
  • Apnea refers to a complete cessation of airflow.


In practice, breathing patterns are often described by their gross appearance and tend to have classic associations.  For example, rapid deep breathing (ie, Kussmaul) is associated with metabolic acidosis; slow, shallow breathing is associated with respiratory depression (eg, opioid intoxication).

Kussmaul



Kussmaul respiration is a pattern of rapid, deep breathing associated with acute metabolic acidosis (eg, diabetic ketoacidosis, toxic alcohol ingestion).  It represents respiratory compensation through hyperventilation to induce respiratory alkalosis (

).

Cheyne-Stokes



Cheyne-Stokes respiration is a periodic breathing pattern that alternates between hyperventilation (rapid, deep breathing) followed by hypopnea (shallow, slow breathing) or complete apnea.  The cycle repeats every 30 seconds to 2 minutes.  It is associated with:



  • Severe heart failure.
  • Stroke or diffuse brain injury.
  • Metabolic derangements (eg, uremia).


Normally, rising arterial CO2 levels immediately signal the medulla to increase minute ventilation to quickly blow CO2 back down to normal ranges.  In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, delayed feedback from central chemoreceptors (eg, sluggish circulation in heart failure) causes CO2 to rise excessively.  This is followed by overcorrection via hyperventilation, causing CO2 levels to drop too low.  The low CO2 levels suppress the chemoreceptors, triggering hypoventilation or apnea until CO2 builds up again.  This restarts the cycle of apnea followed by gradually increasing and then decreasing (crescendo-decrescendo) tidal volumes  (

ðŸ“Š View Table: video 2
).

Ondine curse



Ondine curse refers to central hypoventilation due to congenital (eg, PHOX2B mutation) or acquired lesions (eg, tumor) affecting the medullary respiratory center.  Automatic involuntary respiration is lost, particularly during sleep.  Sensitivity to acidosis or hypercapnia is also severely blunted or lost entirely.  Constant voluntary effort is required (ie, the patient must always remember to breathe).  It usually requires lifelong mechanical ventilation.

Apneustic breathing



Apneustic breathing is a pattern of prolonged inspiration, a long pause, and a very short expiration, which is associated with pontine damage (eg, herniation).  The pons regulates the inspiratory time through its pneumotaxic versus apneustic centers.

Ataxic (Bitot) breathing



Ataxic (Bitot) breathing involves erratic, unpredictable breaths that vary significantly in frequency, duration, and depth.  It is associated with widespread damage to multiple areas of the CPG (eg, pons, medulla).

Agonal breathing



Agonal breathing is a disorganized respiratory pattern that occurs in patients near death; it is characterized by irregular gasping or guppy-like breaths.  It results from generalized dysfunction of all respiratory control centers and is often accompanied by loss of upper airway tone (eg, gurgling, death-rattle).

Summary



The brainstem's central pattern generator, consisting of medullary and pontine centers, establishes an automatic tidal pattern that can be modified by voluntary and involuntary inputs.  The medullary respiratory centers (pre-BÃ¶tzinger complex, dorsal and ventral respiratory groups) set the native respiratory rate, whereas the pontine centers (pneumotaxic and apneustic centers) determine inspiratory duration.  Tidal breathing can be modulated by voluntary control (eg, cortex), emotional responses (eg, limbic system), and feedback from chemoreceptors (pH, CO2, O2) and mechanoreceptors (eg, muscle spindles).  Abnormal patterns include Cheyne-Stokes respiration (eg, heart failure), Kussmaul respiration (eg, metabolic acidosis), and apneustic breathing (eg, pontine injury).
